reviewText: The series starts out nicely but quickly turns bland, mostly due to dreadful choices in scripting.  The director covers major events in history in banal conversations between characters, instead of actual film scenes.  For example, the major battles of the war are glossed over, and the famous Boston tea party is covered in a five minute discussion between John Adams and his brother Sam Adams.  This is the major flaw with this series.  The most profound example is how the film handled the American victory in the War of Independence: at the very climax of the war, when America wins its independence, all we see is John Adams in his sick bed, receiving news of the event.  How pathetic.  You'd think they could be a little more creative than that.  I mean, if JFK had a cold during the first moon landing, do you think his film biography would show him sick in bed reading the news, or would it still show the Apollo moon landing?Paul Giamatti plays a wonderful John Adams.  He is very convincing.  And the early scenes between him and his wife, portrayed by Laura Linney, are quite touching.  Their early years together are fascinating.  But as the time passes, I found myself less and less interested in John Adams and more interested in the surrounding events which were not portrayed.  I found myself wondering what was the point?The series has some wonderful sets, like the recreation of Boston harbor filled with British warships, and the royal court in France.  Some of the scenes of John Adams in France are startling, especially the royal dinner party.  All the french are terrible snobs and yet they look completely ridiculous in their wigs and heavy, heavy make-up (the men were the worst).Unfortunately, it is all wasted.  The movie has many opportunities to excel, but falls far short. The best example perhaps is Adams' vice-presidency.  The film briefly talks about a conspiracy to keep him from becoming president, and offers some vague hints about collusion between Washington and Hamilton to control the government.  Yet this shocking revelation is glossed over in favor of other scenes where Adams is simply treated by his fellows with a lack of respect.  An entire episode should have been spent just on this early political intrigue.

reviewText: The most noticeable and amazing feature of this miniseries is the production design, including sets, locations, costumes, makeup and more. Their chemistry helps them to show the love between John and Abigail Adams through all the difficulties of their life together, including the loss of a son, John's struggles with the new American republic, and his extended absence overseas while his family remains at home.The actors playing Washington, Jefferson, and Franklin also deserve praise for their portrayal of these flawed yet profoundly influential men.It is sobering to note that these founding fathers wanted peace rather than war, and that they remained firm in their belief in trying to do the right thing and uphold the Constitution rather than cave in to others who would have pressured them to compromise on their values.

reviewText: Portraying history in a drama is a complex thing to do; ignore one event and you upset one group while if you take great words spoken but put them in a new context that is more dramatic to make it more interesting and vital on screen you upset purists but stay true to what occurred in history and you run the risk of creating a show that could easily become boring for many people. A drama is exactly that--not history nor does it pretend to be. As drama "John Adams" is gripping giving us insight and allowing us to understand our founding fathers as complex human beings.The cast does an outstanding job of humanizing these people from history making it possible to relate to their actions whether they be honorable or petty.Although based on David McCullough bestselling biography, the producers and writer Kirk Ellis used other sources in addition to the biography by McCullough to give us a broader view of the time and the drama that surrounded Adams and the birth of our country.The Blu-ray looks positively stunning with a sharp, detailed transfer that has more depth than I saw when I rented the regular DVD. Dark scenes in particular benefit from the high definition format with richer and more accurate detail. The audio sounds terrific throughout with a nice surround lossless mix.For those that are concerned with 100% historical accuracy, I'd suggest reading McCullough's book and other information on Adams (because as good as McCullough's book IS he also shows a certain bias towards his subject as he interprets Adams thoughts and actions based on his writings and the writings of others)but as far as a historical drama, "John Adams" is hard to beat. For those who can't stand the "unsteady cam" shooting style that is pretty common today, you won't find a lot of long, traditional Hollywood steady shots here. The style is designed to add to the drama and create a sense of "being there"; whether or not that happens will be up to the viewer and whether or not you can tolerate that style.
summary: Exceptionally good historical drama  with great performances.

reviewText: Though most people may be drawn to this HBO miniseries for its look at the founding fathers and events of our nation in the early years of existence, I would like to add another reason (well, two actually): the gritty realism that the period is portrayed in, and the incredible acting that really brings the characters to life.Now, don't get me wrong...this series is indeed a fascinating look at the formative years of the United States of America through the prism of John Adams' existence.  Though those events now take on an air of legend, viewers will quickly take pleasure in seeing the events not portrayed as overly epic (unless they actually were!) but as the real-life struggles of some pioneer thinkers.However, what continues to stick in my mind after viewing the entire series is how "real" the entire experience seemed.  From the macro level (like the general living conditions and attitudes towards women/slavery) to the micro level (the crude nature of medicine and the sound of flies that can be heard buzzing in almost every scene), it felt as if I really had been transported to that time period.Also not to be overlooked is the incredible acting throughout the series.  Paul Giammatti (Adams) is one of the most underrated character actors of the modern day, and yet he is matched word for word by Laura Linney (Abigail Adams).  The actors portraying such characters as Thomas Jefferson, Benjamin Franklin, and George Washington are even able to bring forth the traits of the real-life luminaries they are portraying.Thus, I would recommend this seven-part miniseries to pretty much any viewer who has any interest in historical topics whatsoever.  Experts on the period will enjoy the realism of the series, while more casual viewers will just be transported away to a life that, while difficult, produced men and women that turned the U.S. into a nation to be reckoned with.
summary: Gritty Realism And Incredible Acting Make This Miniseries A Rousing Success
